metadata.guideline_reference: MOON Group Guidelines, Sports Medicine Australia ACL Guidelines

patient_profile.name: Thomas Bakker
patient_profile.sport: Football (soccer) - amateur club, plays central midfielder

injury_and_surgery.mechanism_of_injury: Non-contact pivot during football match - planted left foot, rotated to pass, felt 'pop' and immediate instability
injury_and_surgery.initial_presentation: Immediate swelling, unable to weight-bear, positive Lachman
injury_and_surgery.imaging: MRI confirmed complete ACL rupture, no meniscal or other ligament damage
injury_and_surgery.post_op_protocol: Surgeon protocol - weight-bearing as tolerated, brace locked in extension for 2 weeks, ROM progression per PT

current_status_8_weeks_post_op.patient_narrative: The surgery went well and I've been doing my exercises every day. The knee feels stable now, not like before surgery. But it's still stiff and weak, and I'm worried about how long until I can play again. My teammates are doing well this season and I'm missing it. My coach keeps asking when I'll be back. I'm doing everything the physio says but I just want to get back on the pitch.
current_complaints: Anterior knee pain with prolonged kneeling (graft site)

pain_status.aggravating: Kneeling, prolonged sitting with knee bent, stairs down

observation.gait: Mild antalgic pattern, slightly reduced stance time on left, minimal limp
observation.swelling: Trace effusion only (significant improvement from earlier weeks)
observation.muscle_bulk: Visible quadriceps atrophy left vs right
observation.scar: Well-healed patellar tendon and tibial incision scars

range_of_motion.patella_mobility: Slightly reduced inferior glide (compared to right)

laxity_testing.pivot_shift: Negative - not performed, graft too early

single_leg_squat.left: Can perform to 45° with knee valgus tendency and trunk lean

functional_tests.hop_tests: Not yet indicated - criteria not met

acl_rsi.interpretation: Low psychological readiness (cutoff for safe RTS is typically >56)

criteria_not_met: Quad LSI still only 45% (goal >60% for phase 3)

phase_3_criteria_strength_8_16_weeks.status: Ready to progress with focus on quadriceps
goals: Single leg squat with good control

required: Single leg squat without dynamic valgus
running_criteria.current_status: Not ready - quad LSI 45%, neuromuscular control insufficient

activity_limitations.qualifier_description: Complete problem - not cleared for football

personal_factors.motivation: Very high - wants to return ASAP
personal_factors.impatience: Present - risk for pushing too hard
personal_factors.psychological_readiness: Low (ACL-RSI 48) - fear of re-injury present despite not expressing it openly
personal_factors.re_injury_fear: Present but may be masked by desire to return

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to run due to insufficient strength and neuromuscular control
underlying_impairments: Dynamic knee valgus during single leg activities

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to perform single leg squat with good alignment
problems.participation_impact: Indicates high re-injury risk if return to sport attempted

problems.activity_limitation: Unable to participate in football training or matches
underlying_impairments: Not cleared for running, jumping, cutting
problems.participation_impact: Missing competitive season, social isolation from team

problems.activity_limitation: Anterior knee pain limits kneeling and prolonged knee flexion
problems.participation_impact: Affects daily activities, may limit certain exercises

long_term_goal.goal: Safe return to competitive football with <10% re-injury risk, meeting all return-to-sport criteria

medium_term_goals.goal: Initiate running program with Quad LSI >70%, no effusion, good single leg squat mechanics
criteria: Single leg squat without dynamic valgus

medium_term_goals.goal: Running 20 minutes continuously without pain or swelling

short_term_goals.goal: Achieve full knee flexion ROM equal to right side (145°)
short_term_goals.interventions: Flexion mobilization, heel slides, stationary bike with progression
Progressive resistance training, emphasis on quad hypertrophy and strength

short_term_goals.goal: Perform 10 single leg squats to 60° without dynamic knee valgus
short_term_goals.interventions: Neuromuscular training, visual feedback, hip strengthening

short_term_goals.goal: Manage anterior knee pain to NPRS ≤1 with activity modification and patellar tendon loading program
short_term_goals.interventions: Isometric quad loading, avoid aggravating positions, ice PRN

intervention_plan.treatment_approach: Criteria-based progression, not time-based. Focus on quadriceps strength, neuromuscular control, and addressing psychological readiness alongside physical rehabilitation.

exercises: Leg press (double leg progressing to single leg bias)
Knee extensions (limited range progressing to full per protocol)
Squats (double leg to single leg progression)
interventions.progression_criteria: Increase load when can complete 12 reps with good form, no increased swelling
interventions.evidence: Strong - quad strength is primary predictor of function and re-injury risk

interventions.rationale: Hamstrings are ACL agonist, protect graft during deceleration

interventions.intervention: Hip abduction, external rotation, extension exercises
interventions.rationale: Hip weakness contributes to dynamic knee valgus (re-injury risk factor)

interventions.intervention: Progressive balance and movement quality training
exercises: Single leg squat with mirror/video feedback
interventions.focus: Eliminate dynamic knee valgus, improve knee control
interventions.evidence: Strong - neuromuscular training reduces ACL re-injury risk

interventions.goal: Achieve full flexion equal to contralateral

interventions.rationale: Maintain fitness while not cleared for running

interventions.intervention: Address fear of re-injury and psychological readiness
strategies: Use ACL-RSI to track and discuss progress
Consider sports psychology referral if needed
interventions.evidence: Moderate - psychological factors predict RTS and re-injury
interventions.coaching_note: ACL-RSI of 48 is concerning. Don't ignore this - high fear of re-injury is associated with both failure to return AND actual re-injury.

interventions.intervention: Manage expectations and involve in decision-making
topics: Why criteria-based progression is safer than time-based
Re-injury risk statistics (5-25% depending on factors)
Why quad strength matters for knee protection

return_to_sport_testing_battery.when: Before clearance for full sport return (typically 9+ months)

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Clearing for running at 12 weeks just because 'that's when protocols say' despite not meeting criteria
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: What are the criteria for running progression? Does this patient meet them? What are the risks of progressing before criteria are met?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Focusing only on physical criteria and missing the low ACL-RSI score
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient's ACL-RSI is 48. What does this tell you? How does psychological readiness affect return to sport outcomes?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Clearing patient for sport return early because they're eager and pressuring you
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient wants to return for the end of season. How do you balance patient goals with safety? What would you say to him about timing?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Focusing only on knee exercises when hip weakness is contributing to valgus
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: You've noticed dynamic knee valgus. What muscle groups control knee position during single leg activities? Is this purely a knee problem?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Ignoring the patellar tendon pain as 'normal' without management
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient has donor site pain with kneeling and certain exercises. How might you address this while continuing to strengthen the quadriceps?

reasoning_traps_for_this_case.description: Clearing for sport based on single hop test without comprehensive battery
reasoning_traps_for_this_case.coaching_response: The patient passed the single leg hop test. Is he ready to return to football? What other criteria should be met?

step_1_data_collection: What criteria would you assess to determine if this patient is ready to progress to running?
Why is the quad LSI important? What's the current value and what does it mean?
What does the ACL-RSI score tell you? Why is this relevant?
What graft was used and does this affect your rehabilitation approach?
step_2_problem_statements: You've identified 'weak quadriceps' as a problem. How would you reframe this as an activity limitation?
How does the inability to run connect to the participation restriction of not playing football?
What's the relationship between dynamic knee valgus and re-injury risk?
step_3_goal_setting: Your goal is 'return to football.' Is this SMART? How would you make it more specific?
What specific criteria define 'safe return to sport'?
How do you set goals with a patient who wants to return faster than is safe?
step_4_intervention_selection: Why are you prioritizing quadriceps strengthening?
How will you address the dynamic knee valgus?
What's your plan for the low psychological readiness score?
How will you maintain cardiovascular fitness while he can't run?
step_7_reevaluation: When will you reassess quad LSI?
What criteria must be met before initiating a running program?
How will you know if the patient is ready for sport-specific training?

key_education_messages: Re-injury risk is real (15-25% for young athletes returning to pivoting sports) - we want to minimize this
Criteria-based rehabilitation is safer than time-based - your knee tells us when you're ready, not the calendar
Quad strength is protective - every 1% increase in quad symmetry reduces re-injury risk
Psychological readiness matters - fear of re-injury affects performance and may actually increase injury risk
The process takes 9-12 months typically - this is frustrating but protective
You're not just waiting - you're actively preparing your knee to handle the demands of football
